title: HAT (Hemorrhage After Thrombolysis) Score for Predicting Post-tPA Hemorrhage
description: Predicts hemorrhage risk after tPA administration in acute ischemic stroke patients. Helps determine risk/benefit of tPA in borderline cases and identify patients needing closest monitoring.

parameters.name: diabetes_or_glucose
parameters.description: History of diabetes mellitus OR initial blood glucose >200 mg/dL (>11.1 mmol/L)

parameters.name: hypodensity_on_ct
parameters.description: Easily visible hypodensity on initial head CT

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of hemorrhage after tPA. Any hemorrhage: 6%, Symptomatic ICH: 2%, Fatal hemorrhage: 0%. Benefits of tPA likely outweigh risks in eligible patients.
Low-moderate risk of hemorrhage after tPA. Any hemorrhage: 16%, Symptomatic ICH: 5%, Fatal hemorrhage: 3%. Consider benefits vs risks carefully, ensure close monitoring if tPA given.
Moderate risk of hemorrhage after tPA. Any hemorrhage: 23%, Symptomatic ICH: 10%, Fatal hemorrhage: 7%. Carefully weigh risks and benefits. Ensure intensive monitoring if tPA given.
High risk of hemorrhage after tPA. Any hemorrhage: 36%, Symptomatic ICH: 15%, Fatal hemorrhage: 6%. Consider alternative treatments. If tPA given, requires intensive monitoring.

Very high risk of hemorrhage after tPA. Any hemorrhage: 78%, Symptomatic ICH: 44%, Fatal hemorrhage: 33%. tPA generally not recommended unless exceptional circumstances. Consider alternative treatments.

references: Lou M, Safdar A, Mehdiratta M, Kumar S, Schlaug G, Caplan L, et al. The HAT Score: a simple grading scale for predicting hemorrhage after thrombolysis. Neurology. 2008 Oct 28;71(18):1417-23. doi: 10.1212/01.wnl.0000330297.58334.dd.

Tsivgoulis G, Frey JL, Flaster M, Sharma VK, Lao AY, Hoover SL, et al. Pre-tissue plasminogen activator blood pressure levels and risk of symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage. Stroke. 2009 Nov;40(11):3631-4. doi: 10.1161/STROKEAHA.109.564096.

Cucchiara B, Kasner SE, Tanne D, Levine SR, Demchuk A, Messe SR, et al. Validation assessment of risk scores to predict postthrombolysis intracerebral haemorrhage. Int J Stroke. 2011 Apr;6(2):109-11. doi: 10.1111/j.1747-4949.2010.00555.x.
formula: HAT Score = Diabetes/Glucose (0-1) + NIHSS Score (0-2) + CT Hypodensity (0-2)
notes: Symptomatic ICH defined as hemorrhage causing clinical deterioration
Score helps objectify tPA risk beyond clinical gestalt
Higher scores correlate with increased hemorrhage risk
If hemorrhage occurs: stop tPA, neurosurgical consult, consider hematology consult
Should not be used as sole criterion to withhold tPA in eligible patients
